query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that more little brown bats infected with the white-nose syndrome fungus survived in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°C, and bats stayed in hibernation longer at 4°C than at 10°C (1013). Two randomized, controlled studies tested a probiotic bacterium treatment: a laboratory study in Canada found that treating little brown bats at the time of infection increased survival within cages and reduced disease symptoms, whereas treating 21 days prior did not increase survival and was associated with worse symptoms (2008); a study in the USA found increased survival for free-flying bats treated within a mine but not for caged bats, and caged bats had similar disease severity to untreated bats (2008). No studies were found that evaluated the effects of culling infected bats (1012), vaccinating bats (1011), restricting human access to bat caves (1010), breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations (2009), treating hibernacula environments to reduce the pathogen reservoir (2007), or decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves (2006).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1013",
  "action_title": "Modify bat hibernacula environments to increase survival of bats infected with white-nose syndrome",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of modifying hibernacula environments to increase the survival of bats infected with white-nose syndrome. The study was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that a greater number of little brown bats infected with the white-nose syndrome fungus survived in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Behaviour change (1 study): One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats infected with the white-nose syndrome fungus stayed in hibernation for longer in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°"
}

{
  "action_id": "2008",
  "action_title": "Treat bats for infection with white-nose syndrome",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium to reduce white-nose syndrome infection. One study was in Canada and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome (but not 21 days prior) increased survival within cages in a laboratory. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium within a mine increased survival for free-flying bats, but not caged bats.
Condition (2 studies): One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that little brown bats caged in a laboratory and treated with a probiotic bacterium at the time of infection with white-nose syndrome had reduced symptoms of the disease, but bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms. One randomized, controlled study in the USA found that little brown bats kept within cages in a mine and treated with a probiotic bacterium had a similar severity of white-nose syndrome to untreated bats.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?
relevant_summary: Action documents identify the following structures to facilitate bat crossings at roads and railways: green bridges (used by 97% of crossing bats in one UK study) [979]; bat gantries/bridges [978]; overpasses, including vegetated overpasses with planters [977]; hop-overs [980]; underpasses and culverts [976]; and plantings or fencing to divert bats to safe crossing points, such as artificial hedgerows [981].

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "979",
  "action_title": "Install green bridges as road/railway crossing structures for bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of installing green bridges as road crossing structures for bats. The study was in the UK.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)      

Use (1 study): One study in the UK found that a green bridge was used by 97% of bats crossing a road."
}

{
  "action_id": "978",
  "action_title": "Install bat gantries or bat bridges as road/railway crossing structures for bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies evaluated the effects of installing bat gantries as road crossing structures for bats. Two studies were in the UK and one in France.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)      

Use (3 studies): Two replicated studies (including one site comparison) in the UK found that fewer bats used bat gantries than crossed the road below at traffic height, and one bat gantry was not used at all. One replicated study in France found that a temporary bat gantry was used by three bat species/species groups, but almost half of crossing bats flew over the road at other locations."
}

{
  "action_id": "977",
  "action_title": "Install overpasses as road/railway crossing structures for bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of installing overpasses as road crossing structures for bats. Three studies were in Europe and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One site comparison study in Australia found that the same number of bat species were recorded at an overpass and in nearby forest and bushland.

POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)      

Use (3 studies): Two replicated studies (including one site comparison) in Ireland and France found that two or three bat species/species groups used overpasses but up to three-quarters of bats crossed the road below at traffic height or crossed at other nearby locations. One study in the UK found that an overpass with planters was used by two-thirds of crossing bats, and an unvegetated overpass with a paved road over it was not used by crossing bats."
}

{
  "action_id": "976",
  "action_title": "Install underpasses or culverts as road/railway crossing structures for bats",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eight studies evaluated the effects of installing underpasses or culverts as road crossing structures for bats. Seven studies were in Europe and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (8 STUDIES)      

Use (8 studies): Eight studies (including six replicated studies) in Germany, Ireland, the UK, Australia and France found that bats used underpasses and culverts below roads, and crossed over the roads above them, in varying proportions. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that bat species adapted to cluttered habitats used small culverts and underpasses more than bat species adapted to open or edge habitats. One replicated, site comparison study in France found that the use of underpasses by five bat species was influenced by underpass type and height, road width, and the amount of forest and hedgerows in the surrounding landscape."
}

{
  "action_id": "981",
  "action_title": "Divert bats to safe crossing points over or under roads/railways with plantings or fencing",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of diverting bats using an artificial hedgerow on bat populations. The study was in Switzerland.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)      

Use (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Switzerland found that up to one fifth of lesser horseshoe bats within a colony flew along an artificial hedgerow to commute."
}

query: How do different methods for restricting public access to bat hibernation sites, such as gates versus fences, compare in their effects on bat populations?
relevant_summary: Cave gates: Evidence is mixed. Across four before-and-after studies, three reported more or similar numbers of bats after gates were installed, while one reported fewer; a replicated before-and-after study found population increases or reduced declines for 13 of 20 Indiana bat colonies, whereas a site comparison in Spain found no difference in population growth between caves with and without gates [999]. One study found higher body mass loss in bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate versus an unmodified cave [999]. Behaviourally, studies reported more circling and fewer entries at cave entrances after gating, sensitivity to bar spacing and gate design, and significantly fewer bats emerging from a gated cave than from a comparable cave with a fence [999]. Mine gates: Findings include fewer bat species entering mines after gating and fewer bats at some gated mines, although bat activity remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines in one controlled study; multiple studies recorded more circling and fewer entries after gates, and collisions with gates occurred in up to 7% of bats at mine entrances [1963]. Fences: A site comparison in Spain reported no difference in population growth or occupancy between caves with and without fencing or gates [1991]. In the USA, significantly more southeastern myotis and gray myotis emerged after a steel gate was replaced with a fence, and a cave comparison found more bats emerging where a fence was used than where a gate was installed [1991, 999].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"bat hibernation sites gates fences public access restricting effects on bat populations","k":3,"offset":0}
{"query_string":"bat cave gating fence restrict human access hibernation roost effects population","k":3,"offset":3}
{"query_string":"bat cave gating fence restrict human access hibernation roost effects population","k":3,"offset":6}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "999",
  "action_title": "Install and maintain cave gates to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of installing cave gates on bat populations. Six studies were in the USA and five studies were in Europe.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (7 STUDIES)

Abundance (7 studies): Three of four before-and-after studies (including one replicated study and one controlled study) in the Netherlands, the USA, Spain and Turkey found more or similar numbers of bats in caves and a bunker after gates were installed to restrict public access. The other study found fewer bats in caves after gates were installed. Two before-and-after studies in the USA and Spain found more bats within two caves after the size of the gated entrances were increased. One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that installing cave gates resulted in population increases or decreased rates of decline for 13 of 20 colonies of Indiana bat. One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Condition (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate over the entrance lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave.

BEHAVIOUR (5 STUDIES)   

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the occupancy rates of bats roosting in caves with and without cave gates.
Behaviour change (4 studies): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after and site comparison study in the USA found that bats at cave entrances circled more and entered caves less after gates were installed. One replicated study in the USA found that bats flew through gates with a funnel design more frequently than gates with a round bar or angle iron design. One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that fewer bats flew through cave gates when the spacing between horizontal bars was reduced. One before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate installed compared with a cave with a fence."
}

{
  "action_id": "1991",
  "action_title": "Install fencing around cave entrances to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of installing fencing around cave entrances on bat populations. One study was in the USA and one study was in Spain.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates of bats roosting in caves with and without fencing or gates installed.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)   

Use (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the occupancy rates of bats roosting in caves with and without fencing or gates installed.
Behaviour change (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that significantly more southeastern myotis bats and gray myotis bats emerged from a cave after a steel gate was replaced with a fence."
}

{
  "action_id": "1963",
  "action_title": "Install and maintain gates at mine entrances to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Nine studies evaluated the effects of installing gates at mine entrances on bat populations. Eight studies were in the USA and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that fewer bat species entered mines after gates were installed.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or before-and-after studies in the USA and Australia found fewer bats in mines or at mine entrances after gates were installed. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that bat activity (relative abundance) remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines, and decreased at two gated mines.

BEHAVIOUR (6 STUDIES)      

Use (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the USA found that 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, however bats abandoned four mines with ‘ladder’ design gates. One replicated study in the USA found that gate design and time since gate installation had varied effects on the presence of four bat species.
Behaviour change (4 studies): Four replicated, before-and-after or site comparison studies in the USA and Australia found that bats at mine entrances circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed.

OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Collisions with gates (1 study): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that up to 7% of bats at mine entrances collided with mine gates."
}

{
  "action_id": "1002",
  "action_title": "Impose restrictions on cave visits",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of imposing restrictions on cave visits on bat populations. One study was in each of the USA, Canada, Madagascar, and Turkey.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): Two before-and-after studies in Canada and Turkey found that bat populations within caves increased after restrictions on cave visitors were imposed.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Behaviour change (2 studies): One study in the USA found that reducing the number of people within cave tour groups did not have a significant effect on the number of take-offs, landings or overall activity (bat movements) of a cave myotis colony roosting within the cave. One study in Madagascar found that increasing visitor approach distances, along with avoiding direct illumination of bats, reduced the alertness and number of take-offs of Madagascan rousettes during experimental cave tours."
}

One study found higher body mass loss in bats hibernating in a cave with a wall and gate versus an unmodified cave [999]. Behaviourally, studies reported more circling and fewer entries at cave entrances after gating, sensitivity to bar spacing and gate design, and significantly fewer bats emerging from a gated cave than from a comparable cave with a fence [999]. Mine gates: Findings include fewer bat species entering mines after gating and fewer bats at some gated mines, although bat activity remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines in one controlled study; multiple studies recorded more circling and fewer entries after gates, and collisions with gates occurred in up to 7% of bats at mine entrances [1963]. Fences: A site comparison in Spain reported no difference in population growth or occupancy between caves with and without fencing or gates [1991]. In the USA, significantly more southeastern myotis and gray myotis emerged after a steel gate was replaced with a fence, and a cave comparison found more bats emerging where a fence was used than where a gate was installed [1991, 999].","action_ids":["999","1963","1991"]}

query: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?
relevant_summary: Evidence from operational adjustments shows multiple approaches reduce bat fatalities at onshore wind farms: (1) Increasing turbine cut-in speed reduced bat fatalities in 10 of 12 studies (USA and Canada), with two studies finding no reduction due to small samples or short treatment periods (action_id: 1960). (2) Preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (“feathering”) reduced bat fatalities in five of six studies (USA and Canada), though one study found no reduction (action_id: 970). (3) Automatically reducing blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high reduced bat fatalities in two replicated studies (Germany and USA), for all bats combined and for five species (action_id: 971). (4) Slowing blade rotation at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities in one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada (action_id: 2939).

{"query_string":"onshore wind turbines operational adjustments to reduce bat fatalities curtailment feathering cut-in speed mitigation","k":3,"offset":6}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "970",
  "action_title": "Prevent turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds ('feathering')",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds on bat populations. Five studies were in the USA and one was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Survival (6 studies): Five of six studies (including five replicated, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’), or feathering along with increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other study found that automatically feathering turbine blades at low wind speeds did not reduce bat fatalities.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "1960",
  "action_title": "Increase the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’)",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twelve studies evaluated the effects of increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’) on bat populations. Ten studies were in the USA and two were in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Survival (12 studies): Ten of 12 studies (including 10 replicated, randomized, controlled studies and one before-and-after study) in the USA and Canada found that increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational (‘cut-in speed’), or increasing the cut-in speed along with preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (‘feathering’) resulted in fewer bat fatalities than at conventionally operated turbines. The other two studies found that increasing cut-in speeds did not reduce bat fatalities, but sample sizes were small or treatments were applied for short periods only.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2939",
  "action_title": "Slow rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds on bat populations. The study was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Survival (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada found that bat fatalities were reduced when turbine blades were slowed at low wind speeds.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "971",
  "action_title": "Automatically reduce turbine blade rotation when bat activity is high",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of automatically reducing turbine blade rotation when bat activity is high on bat populations. One study was in Germany, and one in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Survival (2 studies): Two replicated studies (one randomized, controlled and one paired sites study) in Germany and the USA found that automatically reducing the rotation speed of wind turbine blades when bat activity is predicted to be high resulted in fewer bat fatalities for all bat species combined and for five bat species.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

(2) Preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds (“feathering”) reduced bat fatalities in five of six studies (USA and Canada), though one study found no reduction (action_id: 970). (3) Automatically reducing blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high reduced bat fatalities in two replicated studies (Germany and USA), for all bats combined and for five species (action_id: 971). (4) Slowing blade rotation at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities in one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Canada (action_id: 2939).","action_ids":["1960","970","971","2939"]}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1953",
  "action_title": "Use non-lethal measures to prevent bats from accessing fruit in orchards to reduce human-wildlife conflict",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of using non-lethal measures to prevent bats from accessing fruit in orchards to reduce human-wildlife conflict. The studies were in Madagascar and Mauritius.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (2 STUDIES)    

Human-wildlife conflict (2 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies (including one randomized study) in Madagascar and Mauritius found that using an organic deterrent spray, hanging plastic flags in trees, or covering individual tree branches with nylon net bags reduced damage to lychees caused by Madagascan flying foxes or Mauritius fruit bats. One of the studies found that ringing bells in lychee trees deterred most Madagascan flying foxes."
}

{
  "action_id": "2942",
  "action_title": "Provide alternative bat roosts during maintenance work at road/railway bridges and culverts",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of providing alternative bat roosts during maintenance work at road bridges. The study was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Use (1 study): One review in the USA found that bat houses provided as alternative roosts during bridge replacement works were used by fewer Mexican free-tailed bats than the original roost at one site and were not used by bats at all at three sites."
}

{
  "action_id": "1930",
  "action_title": "Exclude bats from roosts during building work",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of excluding bats from roosts during building work on bat populations. The study was in the UK.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)                                                  

Behaviour change (1 study): One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that excluding bats from roosts within buildings did not change roost switching frequency, core foraging areas or foraging preferences of soprano pipistrelle colonies."
}

{
  "action_id": "2052",
  "action_title": "Manage microclimate of artificial bat roosts",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies evaluated the effects of managing the microclimate of artificial bat roosts on bat populations. Two studies were in the UK and one in Spain.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One before-and-after study in Spain found more bats in two artificial roosts within buildings after they had been modified to reduce internal roost temperatures.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that heated bat boxes were used by common pipistrelle bats at one of seven sites, but none were used by maternity colonies. One replicated study in the UK found that none of the 12 heated bat boxes installed within churches were used by displaced Natterer’s bats."
}

relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several non-lethal approaches. In fruit orchards, an organic deterrent spray, hanging plastic flags in trees, covering branches with nylon net bags, and ringing bells deterred bats and reduced fruit damage in replicated, controlled studies in Madagascar and Mauritius [1953]. Replacing culling with non-lethal methods to prevent vampire bats from spreading rabies to humans or livestock has no studies evaluating effects [1979, 1950]. Preventing culling around fruit orchards has no studies evaluating effects [1952]. Carrying out surveillance of bats to prevent spread of disease/viruses to humans has no studies evaluating effects [2005]. Providing alternative roosts during bridge maintenance saw bat houses used less than the original roost at one site and not used at three sites in the USA [2942]. Excluding bats from roosts during building work did not change roost switching frequency, core foraging areas, or foraging preferences of soprano pipistrelle colonies in a replicated, before-and-after study in the UK [1930]. Excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation has no studies evaluating effects [1961]. Managing the microclimate of artificial roosts showed increased bat numbers after reducing internal temperatures in two artificial roosts in Spain, while heated bat boxes in UK sites showed limited or no use, including by displaced Natterer’s bats [2052].

query: How effective are different public education and engagement strategies for improving bat conservation outcomes?
relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of educating the public to improve the perception of bats and improve behaviour towards bats [1000]. No studies were found that evaluated the effects of engaging policymakers to make policy changes beneficial to bats or to influence human behaviours directly beneficial to bats [2041].

query: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, what alternative lighting strategies can be used to minimize disturbance to bats?

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "bat friendly lighting strategies minimize disturbance to bats alternative lighting strategies", "k": 3, "offset": 0}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1994",
  "action_title": "Restrict artificial lighting in caves and around cave entrances",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of restricting artificial lighting in caves on bat populations. The study was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Behaviour change (1 study): One controlled study in the USA found that using low intensity white lights or red lights in caves resulted in fewer bat flights than with full white lighting, but the number of bat movements was similar between all three light treatments."
}

{
  "action_id": "2021",
  "action_title": "Use red lighting rather than other lighting colours",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies evaluated the effects of red lighting on bat populations. Two studies were in the Netherlands and one was in the UK.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One replicated, controlled, site comparison study in the Netherlands found that red lighting resulted in higher activity (relative abundance) for one of three bat species groups than white or green lighting. One site comparison study in the Netherlands found that culverts illuminated with red light had similar activity of commuting Daubenton’s bats as culverts illuminated with white or green light.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)         

Behaviour (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the UK found that more soprano pipistrelles emerged from a roost when lit with red light than when lit with white light, but no difference was found between red and blue lights."
}

{
  "action_id": "1019",
  "action_title": "Restrict timing of lighting",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of restricting the timing of lighting on bat populations. The study was in France.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired sites study in France found that turning off streetlights for part of the night resulted in mixed results for activity (relative abundance), depending on bat species, when compared with leaving streetlights switched on all night.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"bat lighting strategies spectrum intensity shielding directional lighting warm colours dimming motion sensors hoods louvres", "k": 3, "offset": 6}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3628",
  "action_title": "Change the colour (spectral composition) of lighting",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies evaluated the effects of changing the colour (spectral composition) of lighting on reptile populations. Two studies were in the USA and one was in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Behaviour change (3 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies (including one randomized study) in the USA and Australia found that yellow-tinted incandescent lighting did not affect the seaward orientation of loggerhead turtle hatchlings, whereas four other types of lighting did, and that hatchlings were disoriented in fewer trials by red lighting than by amber lighting. One replicated, controlled study in the USA found in laboratory trials that filtering out high wavelengths did not prevent loggerhead or green turtles crawling towards light sources."
}

query: To protect bats from the impacts of mining operations, what actions can be taken during and after mine closure and reclamation?
relevant_summary: Relevant actions identified include: excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation, though no studies have evaluated effects on bat populations [1961]; retaining access points for bats following mine closures, with no studies evaluating population effects [1962]; installing and maintaining gates at mine entrances to restrict public access, with nine studies reporting mixed outcomes including reduced species richness in one study, reduced abundance in two studies, stable or increased activity at five of seven gated mines and decreased at two in one study, continued use of 43 of 47 mines 12 years post-gating with abandonment at four mines with ‘ladder’ gates, varied effects by gate design and time since installation, increased circling and reduced entry at entrances, and up to 7% of bats colliding with gates in one study [1963]; maintaining microclimate in closed/abandoned mines, with one study reporting increased numbers of hibernating bats after closing a man-made entrance to modify microclimate [1964]; reopening entrances to closed mines and making them suitable for roosting bats, with no studies found on effects [1965]; relocating bats from reclaimed mines to alternative subterranean roost sites, with no studies evaluating effects [975]; and providing artificial subterranean bat roosts to replace roosts in reclaimed mines, with no studies evaluating effects [974].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "bats mining operations closure reclamation actions protect bats during and after mine closure", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string":"bats mining operations closure reclamation actions protect bats during and after mine closure","k":3,"offset":3}
{"query_string":"bats mining operations closure reclamation actions protect bats during and after mine closure","k":3,"offset":6}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1963",
  "action_title": "Install and maintain gates at mine entrances to restrict public access",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Nine studies evaluated the effects of installing gates at mine entrances on bat populations. Eight studies were in the USA and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that fewer bat species entered mines after gates were installed.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison or before-and-after studies in the USA and Australia found fewer bats in mines or at mine entrances after gates were installed. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that bat activity (relative abundance) remained stable or increased at five of seven gated mines, and decreased at two gated mines.

BEHAVIOUR (6 STUDIES)      

Use (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the USA found that 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, however bats abandoned four mines with ‘ladder’ design gates. One replicated study in the USA found that gate design and time since gate installation had varied effects on the presence of four bat species.
Behaviour change (4 studies): Four replicated, before-and-after or site comparison studies in the USA and Australia found that bats at mine entrances circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed.

OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Collisions with gates (1 study): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that up to 7% of bats at mine entrances collided with mine gates."
}

{
  "action_id": "1964",
  "action_title": "Maintain microclimate in closed/abandoned mines",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of maintaining the microclimate in an abandoned mine on bat populations. The study was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One before-and-after study in the USA found that modifying the microclimate of an abandoned mine by closing a man-made entrance resulted in a greater number of bats hibernating within the mine.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}
